With assistance from my two daughters, I have completed the attached pioneer questionnaires to the best of my ability, and hope the odds and ends of reminiscences contained therein provide interesting revelations to anyone using them in the years to come.

My grandparents, John and Caroline Seibold, emigrated from Roumania to Canada in 1882, anxious to leave the strict military life which predominated in Europe generally, and take up a new way of life in the land of promise, sponsored by the Baptist Church.

In their party were relatives and friends numbering twenty-one. They came by boat from Roumania to Halifax, then by train as far as Qu'Appelle, which was as far as the railroad went at that time. The settlers found their way to what is now known as Edenwold District in the wagons supplied each married couple by the Federal Government, pulled by a team of oxen. Also supplied was a hand plow and a hundredweight of flour. This was their start in this brave, new land.

In 1885, when the Rebellion and other activities had taken most of the members of the N.W.M.P. up around the Battlefords, my Uncle George and my Uncle John (members of the original twenty-one) were called into the Home Guard at the Barracks in Regina, along with some of the other settlers, to protect the home front. Uncle John Seibold, a tall, dark and handsome lad of nineteen, was known as "Black Jack", around the Barracks.

In April, 1886, Christian and Dora Seibold, my parents, came to Canada to join the early settlers, bringing with them their two small sons, Frederick and Gottlieb, and in the Fall of that year, my twin sister and I were born in a little dug-out on the side of a hill, which was our parents' home. October 26th, 1886 -- the first twins born to white settlers in what is now Saskatchewan. My sister was named Catharine and I was named Elizabeth, after the two famous queens, and we proved to be an oddity, as often in the years when we were small, the Indians would walk into our home to have a look at the two babies who were identical twins, and be gone again almost before my mother could turn around.

With the arrival of twins in the community, the need for a cow was greatly increased, so each family put in what little money they had and between six families they were able to buy one community cow from Mr. Goodwin, who lived nearby and had driven cattle west from Ontario. The cow cost $17.00. A Mrs. Laperd presented Mother with a Plymouthrock hen with a setting of eggs.

My grandparents, John and Caroline Seibold, emigrated from Roumania to Canada in 1882, anxious to leave the strict military life which predominated in Europe generally, and take up a new way of life in the land of promise, sponsored by the Baptist Church.

In their party were relatives and friends numbering twenty-one. They came by boat from Roumania to Halifax, then by train as far as Qu'Appelle, which was as far as the railroad went at that time. The settlers found their way to what is now known as Edenwold District in the wagons supplied each married couple by the Federal Government, pulled by a team of oxen. Also supplied was a hand plow and a hundredweight of flour. This was their start in this brave, new land.

In 1885, when the Rebellion and other activities had taken most of the members of the N.W.M.P. up around the Battlefords, my Uncle George and my Uncle John (members of the original twenty-one) were called into the Home Guard at the Barracks in Regina, along with some of the other settlers, to protect the home front. Uncle John Seibold, a tall, dark and handsome lad of nineteen, was known as "Black Jack", around the Barracks.

In April, 1886, Christian and Dora Seibold, my parents, came to Canada to join the early settlers, bringing with them their two small sons, Frederick and Gottlieb, and in the Fall of that year, my twin sister and I were born in a little dug-out on the side of a hill, which was our parents' home. October 26th, 1886 -- the first twins born to white settlers in what is now Saskatchewan. My sister was named Catharine and I was named Elizabeth, after the two famous queens, and we proved to be an oddity, as often in the years when we were small, the Indians would walk into our home to have a look at the two babies who were identical twins, and be gone again almost before my mother could turn around.

With the arrival of twins in the community, the need for a cow was greatly increased, so each family put in what little money they had and between six families they were able to buy one community cow from Mr. Goodwin, who lived nearby and had driven cattle west from Ontario. The cow cost $17.00. Mrs. Laperd presented Mother with a Plymouthrock hen with a setting of eggs.
Long Lake was completely dry the year we were born. Our Father contracted to make the hay in the Lake and haul it down to Regina for the Mounted Police, and at the conclusion of having time all the men left their rates and mowers where they were until the following season; but when the Spring arrived, a deluge filled the Lake and they couldn't salvage their machinery. They are probably there yet.

As was the case with most of the early settlers, our family was large—a man's fortune being in his sons and daughters, in those years. There were eleven living children in our family. The twin sister mentioned previously, Mrs. C. Talbot, is presently residing in Victoria, B.C.; and she intends being in Regina this summer for some of the jubilee activities. Five of the children are now deceased; Frederick, William, Christian, Margaret and Magdalena. The others still take an active interest in their communities and are: Gottlieb, retired at New Westminster, B.C., Martin and Lawrence, farmers at Goodsoil, Sask., Mrs. Caroline Brimacombe, Revelstoke, B.C., and Mrs. Mary Betteridge, Regina.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 1

PIONEER DAYS: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can, and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, where it will be preserved as part of the permanent records of our Province.

Name: Mrs. R. Miles
Address: 524A Beverley Avenue, Regina, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: Redwood, Saskatchewan, Canada

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? Redwood, Saskatchewan, Canada
Where had you been living before that? Born, raised, and married at Redwood, Saskatchewan
For how many years did you prepare meals? 30 years
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, coffee, sugar, flour, dried apples and prunes, rice, and oatmeal

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? The majority of white flour we were able to purchase was marked thus on the bag: "X X X" (four X's).
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually by the 100 lb. weight.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Approx. $2.50.
How much did you use graham flour? We were just able to buy graham flour.
Whole wheat flour? We purchased a bushel at a time from our own local mill about once a year.
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? Bagguley
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Approx. $2.50
What other grain products did you use? No other except whole wheat obtained from the mill
Cornmeal? No
Other? Whole Wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Ground in a chopping machine which was drawn by a team of horses

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Approx. $2.50.

Was flour milled locally? Yes.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.35.

What other grain products did you use? Poother. Whole wheat obtained from the mill.

Cornmeal? No.

Other? Whole Wheat

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.

How did you grind it? Ground in a choppin' machine which was drawn by a team of horses.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the numbers of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer. In my very early youth our three meals were made up as follows: this was quite a general feeding for most families of that day - from 1886 on.

Breakfast: - hominy porridge, soup, bread and butter and milk (and perhaps a little meat always our own) bread and butter and tea or coffee or milk.

Dinner: - thick vegetable soup again (possibly dumplings in it) and perhaps a little meat (always our own) bread and butter cheese.

Supper: - thick vegetable soup again (possibly dumplings in it) and perhaps a little meat (always our own) bread and butter cheese.

We never ate very much meat at any time. Of course there was always homemade cheese and fancy breads on hand. Everything was made very plain and wholesome from yeast dough.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any wrappings which you recall in the newspapers and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most of purchased items in the early days were put up in cardboard cartons, wooden boxes or wooden barrels. Can't remember the date when any noticeable change was made.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

In my very early youth our three meals were made up as follows: this was quite a general feeding for most families of that day - from 1886 on -

Breakfast: - homemade bread and butter and coffee.

Dinner: - homemade porridge, soup, bread and butter and milk.

Supper: - think vegetables soup again (possibly dumplings in it) and perhaps a little meat (always our own) bread and butter and tea or coffee or milk.

We never ate very much meat at any time. Of course there was always homemade cheese and fancy breads on hand. Everything was made very plain and wholesome from best dough.

Members of my family, their age, etc., can be obtained from the brief history of my life which is attached to these questionnaires.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the early days as compared with today. Food prepared in my early days was distinctly wholesome and was not refined in any way. People seemed much more healthy than they are today, and I feel that this was so because of the "raw" or "original" way in which we had our food prepared. Things were basically served as they were produced from nature with nothing added and nothing taken away. If we could not buy or produce a type of food we did without it. Everything possible was used and nothing was wasted. Our food was sound work for carrying it and everything possible was done to use every bit of what we would find in the basket or food if it were used in its natural form - milk - bread - butter - vegetables.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

When we moved to Regina in 1924 we began to purchase prepared foods in the stores as we did not have the space in our gardens to grow enough vegetables, etc., to keep us going all year 'round. Of course too we did not have any livestock or hens and this necessitated the purchase of meat, eggs, cheese, butter, etc. However, we did grow as big a garden as possible in the city, and make use of all the produce we received from it by canning, pickling, etc.

During the brief time we lived in the Yellow Grass district when I was a very small child, about 2 weeks prior to Christmas that year my Father left home for Regina to get a supply of groceries. Due to the cold and stormy weather my Father did not get back home until New Years Day. While he was away we had to live on pap (made with boiling milk and enough flour to thicken it) and milk to drink.

We were down to our last spoonful of flour before my Dad got home. We all kept looking for him day after day and all day long. Finally we saw a speck on the horizon as a result of a mirage (commonly seen in the early days). He was about 10 miles from home. When we saw him coming in the early morning my Mother made we children carry hay up on to a hill and we burned it all day so my Father could see it as he was coming closer to home. He finally arrived in the house about 10 P.m. that night. For some time before he arrived we could hear the rattling of the harness and it was like music to our ears.

As soon as he got home we found he was very weary but thankful as were we all.

The horses were played out bucking the storm and snow and we took the blankets off our beds and covered the horses with them in the barn and gave them hot mash to warm them up.

This was the closest our family came to starving to death as I can recall.

A few added recollections of my early life in-so-far as food was concerned are as follows:

When I first came into the world the main foods my parents were able to purchase were flour, coffee, tea, and sugar, dried apples and prunes. Having a cow we had ample supply of milk, butter, and cheese. From these products the large bulk of our food was made. We grew our own vegetables and cured our own meats (ate very little meat), but we had 2 little pigs.

Menu as I recall it for a pioneer family:

Breakfast - bread, butter, and coffee. We had oatmeal porridge in the winter months.

Dinner - vegetable soup, bread and butter and milk

Supper - same as dinner with possibly dumplings. We ate very little meat, but when we did it was some we had cured ourselves.

Sometimes when my folks went to shop, the storekeeper would put in the order a small bag of candies as a treat for we children (without cost).

At Christmas it was a tradition with our family that my mother would supply each child with a clean white handkerchief in which she placed fancy bread goodies she had baked and tied them in the hanky. These would be supplied to any children whom we visited in other homes at that festive season and we children would receive the same when other families visited us. On Christmas morning we would all go to Church and then would be asked to go home with a neighboring family for Christmas dinner.

This same practice was carried out at Easter time, but in addition my mother would color eggs for us (dyes were always available at the stores even in those early days) but I have seen my mother dye eggs with onion skins and odd bits of crepe paper gathered through the years and the eggs would be beautiful.
